1. Habitat Destruction: Climate change can lead to alterations in the distribution and abundance of plant and animal species, leading to a reduction in biodiversity. As temperatures increase, habitats are altered, forcing species to adapt or move to new areas to maintain their survival. This often leads to the destruction of critical habitats, such as forests, wetlands and grasslands, which can cause species loss and further reductions in biodiversity.
2. Increased Frequency and Severity of Extreme Weather Events: Climate change is leading to increased frequency and severity of extreme weather events, such as droughts, floods, hurricanes and heatwaves. These events can cause widespread damage to ecosystems, leading to the loss of habitats and the death of many species. In sub-Saharan Africa, where many species are already threatened due to a combination of habitat loss and over-exploitation, these extreme weather events can cause significant declines in biodiversity and reduce the resilience of ecosystems to future changes.
